content.question: A student is riding on a bus that is traveling east at a constant speed. The student walks toward the front of the bus. A stationary observer outside the bus standing on the road claims that the student is moving faster than the bus. Is the claim correct? Why or why not?

choices.label: No, because the student is included in the same frame of reference as the bus so the student and bus must be traveling at the same speed.
No, because the student, bus, and observer are all included in Earth’s reference frame so the student and bus must be traveling at the same speed.
Yes, because according to the stationary observer, the student’s velocity is the velocity of the bus plus the velocity of the student relative to the bus.
Yes, because according to the stationary observer, the student’s velocity is the difference between the velocity of the bus and the velocity of the student relative to the bus.

content.answer: Yes, because according to the stationary observer, the student’s velocity is the velocity of the bus plus the velocity of the student relative to the bus.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
